cont.entity_a: Versatile focal length functioning like a 32mm, suitable for both photo and video.
cont.entity_b: Nice focal range for general use, including portraits and landscapes.

cont.entity_a: Vivid color and sharpness at f/2.8. Sharp images in low light, even when fully opened.
Barely perceptible barrel distortion on crop sensor, easily corrected in post.
Affordable with good image quality for the price and weight.
cont.entity_b: Not professional grade but suitable for everyday amateur use.

cont.entity_a: Solid build with metal and glass, not lightweight but preferred over cheaper lenses.
cont.entity_b: Plastic build with a girthy appearance. Well-built.

cont.entity_a: No noticeable vignetting; good for wide-angle shots. Heavy vignetting and soft corners, but manageable with knowledge of the curved focal plane.
Some images soft at edges, sharpness improves from f/4.0. Sharp images in low light, even when fully opened.
cont.entity_b: Soft at 28mm, sharpens at lower f-stops. Sharp shots from 50mm-80mm across most f-stops. Best used around f/11 for sharpness.

cont.entity_a: Works well for landscapes and architecture photography with fast and accurate focus. Good for landscapes, night scenes, and indoor family gatherings. Useful for tight spaces, landscapes, and low light.
cont.entity_b: Good for portraits, landscapes, and close-ups.

cont.entity_a: Prone to flaring, recommend using a lens hood.
Solid and fast lens, outperforming some zoom lenses.
Colors can appear lifeless and burnt-out, lacking detail.

Quality.comm: Unbeatable price for the quality offered.

cont.entity_a: Not as good as higher-end lenses but offers excellent value for the price.

cont.entity_b: Works well with both digital and film cameras.
